results.title: Noise [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Sentinel Films, Louise Gartland and Christopher Benz
results.brief_description: A noisy street sweeper hinders the sleep of a man lying in bed. Add to the mix a noisy car reverse parallel parking and the ensuing car alarm as strangers become friends in their unity to stop the noise.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sentinel Films, Louise Gartland and Christopher Benz

results.title: Noise
results.creator_credit: Bailey Film Productions and Don Dickerson
results.brief_description: Raises such questions as: What is the difference between sound and noise? How does noise effect the individual? As the tempo of urban life increases, must the amount of noise also increase? Explores the effect of noise on the daily activities of a family at home, at school, at work, and indicates ways to control noise. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Noir et blanc
results.creator_credit: Les Films du Volcan, Ministère Français de la Culture and Claire Devers
results.brief_description: A shy, world-weary accountant at a health club takes the advice of his employer to have a massage to relieve tension. The man, white and married, begins regular sessions with a taciturn black masseur, and a sadomasochistic relationship quickly develops between the two men. The accountant’s self-revelatory discovery of masochistic pleasure draws him ever more deeply into a world of pain and humiliation, inflicted in an atmosphere of sinister ritual and silent desire. Shot in black-and-white this understated and compelling film offers an oblique look at the cruel complexities of male relationships. Winner of the Camera d’Or at the 1986 Cannes film festival for best first feature, Devers’ film is based on the short story “Desire and the Black Masseur” by Tennessee Williams. Cast includes Francis Frappat, Jacques Martial, Josephine Fresson and Marc Berman. Written by Claire Devers. Photography by Daniel Desbois, Christopher Doyle, Alain Lasfargues and Jean-Paul de Costa. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Noi Tre
results.creator_credit: Istituto Luce Italnoleggio Cinematografico, Duea Film, Rai Uno Radiotelevisione Italiana, Antonio Avati and Pupi Avati
results.brief_description: One of the most delightful films ever made about Mozart, “Noi Tre” is also a delicate and touching study of the last moments of childhood, as the 14 year old prodigy spends summer with his father on Count Pallavicini’s estate preparing for an important exam at the Bologna Philharmonic Academy. However, in between his studies he falls in with the local boys of his own age, and also feels the first stirring’s of love for Antonia, a girl from a nearby villa. Tasting for the first time, the life of a normal 14 year old, Mozart decides to fail the exam.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Istituto Luce Italnoleggio Cinematografico, Duea Film, Rai Uno Radiotelevisione Italiana, Antonio Avati and Pupi Avati

results.title: Noguchi, a sculptor's world
results.brief_description: A film biography of Isamu Noguchi, a foremost modern twentieth century artist, whom Buckminster Fuller called “The comprehensive artist without peer in our time”. Speaking directly to his audience and narrating the film, Noguchi lends insight into his thinking, philosophy and versatile creative life.

results.title: Noel Coward: private lives
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Cedric Messina, Laurence Rees and John Gorrie
results.brief_description: Tape 1 - Private Lives. On the first night of her honeymoon Amanda (Penelope Keith) feels that everything is perfect. The hotel room has a spectacular view, the cocktails are on the way and close by someone is singing a love song. To her horror she discovers that ‘someone’ is actually her ex-husband, also on honeymoon in a neighbouring hotel room. Noel Coward’s script is as relevant today as when it was first written in 1930 when he also played the lead role. The dialogue is quickly paced and full of wit and insightful observations. Tape 2 - Noel Coward: A Private Life. This is a biographical documentary about the life and early success of Noel Coward as a child actor and then as a playwright and performer in the 1920s and ‘30s through to the post war years. The documentary contains footage from his performances as well as interviews with those who knew him providing a revealing insight into Coward’s discrete private life that was significantly separate from his public image.

results.title: Noddy Goes to Toyland
results.brief_description: Noddy is a little wooden fellow who runs away from his father, a woodcarver and goes to Toyland, a play city for children inhabited by a population of wooden and woolly characters. Noddy finds a home there and lots of adventures which he steadfastly encounters and manages to overcome with the help of several good friends like Big Ears and Tessie Bear. Narrated by Richard Briers, Enid Blyton’s popular stories are brought to life by puppets.

results.title: Noddy goes to the fair (K)
results.creator_credit: CPL, Stop Frame Productions, Chris Taylor, Brian Cosgrove, Mark Hall and Simon Bosanquet
results.brief_description: Based on the Noddy stories by Enid Blyton. On a very windy day in Toy Town, a fair comes to town. Mr Plod tries to take away Noddy’s car, but when Bumby retrieves Mr Plod’s hat at the fair he lets Noddy go. Narrated by Richard Briers.

results.title: Noddy goes to school
results.creator_credit: CPL, Stop Frame Productions, Brian Cosgrove and Mark Hall
results.brief_description: Based on the Noddy stories by Enid Blyton. A series of incidents cause Noddy to come to the realisation that he should go to school to learn to read. Narrated by Richard Briers.

results.title: Noddy gets into trouble (K)
results.creator_credit: CPL, Stop Frame Productions, Brian Cosgrove and Mark Hall
results.brief_description: Based on the Noddy stories by Enid Blyton. Noddy feels he is starting an “extra special” day and then finds he is suspected of theft of cakes and tarts because his cap bell was heard at the scene. The townspeople shun him as further thefts occur, but in the end, with the help of Big Ears and Little Ears, Noddy captures the real thief and presents him to Mr Plodd the Policeman. Narrated by Richard Briers.
